author: Neil Docking
title: Mum-of-seven who glassed woman and scarred her for life is spared jail because of her children
text:
Joanne Hodson outside Liverpool Crown Court (Photo: Liverpool Echo) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing! Could   
A woman who launched a glass at a student on a night out and scarred her for life has been spared prison so she can care for her children. 
Leanne Pinney, 21, suffered severe cuts to the face - including a gash to her forehead - which now serves as a permanent reminder of the violent attack. 
Single mum-of-seven Joanne Hodson, 33, threw a drink over her victim before she hurled the glass at her face, after getting angry at a group in a pub. 
But she been spared jail after a judge was told she lives with three of her children, including an autistic six-year-old, and has three others stay at weekends. Joanne Hodson outside Liverpool Crown Court (Photo: Liverpool Echo)

Judge David Aubrey, QC, told her: “While no doubt your children, aged two, six and 14, were asleep in bed, being cared for by a member of the family, you attacked this student. 
“You did so maliciously and you did so without justification. It was, as your victim described, a senseless attack.” 
Liverpool Crown Court heard jobless Hodson was on a date at a pub iat around 1am on October 16 last year when the incident took place, the Liverpool Echo reported . 
CCTV showed her stagger across a dance floor and start screaming at a group, before returning to a table where she had left a half pint glass. 
The victim told the court: “She was extremely angry and a male tried to calm her down. She said ‘f*** off’ and then threw the glass deliberately at my head.” 
Former bodybuilder to stand trial accused of capturing and killing Britain's rarest butterflies Liverpool Crown Court (Photo: MEN) 
Mike Stephenson, prosecuting, said the student felt blood dripping down her face, as “determined” Hodson headed for the exit. 
Another customer stopped Hodson, who struggled with police, and Ms Pinney was taken to hospital. She needed three stitches for a cut above her right eye and treatment for two other wounds. 
Ms Pinney, who missed a week of lectures following the incident, said: “This malicious and senseless attack has knocked my confidence. 
“I have a permanent one-inch scar to my forehead and a smaller scar on the bridge of my nose, which will be a constant reminder.” 
Hodson admitted assault causing actual bodily harm. She has two previous convictions for the same offence in 1999 and 2002. 
Tom Watson, defending, said she was on medication for depression and had a seriously “troubled childhood”. 
He said she was “extremely drunk” on the evening of the incident and thought she had been “drenched” with drink, and retaliated. 
Mr Watson said: “This was outrageous. She is deeply remorseful and she offers her unreserved apology. She says she will never drink again.” 
He said Hodson had three children, aged nine, 10 and 11, who live with their dad, and a 16-year-old son. 
Mr Watson said: “Her eldest boy went into care when she was 16. She has not seen him since he was 11-months-old.” 
He said her mum and sister would care for her children if she was jailed, adding: “Although she would be frightened at the prospect of prison, it’s for her children she is most frightened.”

Judge Aubrey said he had to decide whether to suspend what would otherwise be an “inevitable” prison term. 
The judge said: “If the court imposes an immediate custodial sentence upon you today, inevitably it will impact upon your three children. You of course should of thought of that.” 
Hodson sat with her hands clasped in prayer and burst into tears when the judge handed her 12 months in jail, suspended for two years. 
Judge Aubrey said: “This court intends to restrict your liberty considerably.” 
He also gave her a six-month home curfew, from 8pm to 6am, 220 hours of unpaid work, a 20-day rehabilitation activity and ordered her to pay £400 in compensation. Like us on Facebook
